messages.content: What is introverted thinking?

Introverted thinking - Ti - is logic. Pure individual true-false judgment. You decide what's true or false based on your own analysis, not what the group thinks. It's your personal logical framework running constant Boolean checks: true or false, on or off. No maybes. Every Ti user is building their own system of truth, piece by piece, testing everything that comes in.
How is Ti different from Te?

Ti is individual logic - you verify truth yourself. Te is collective rationale - truth by majority rule and metrics. Ti asks "is this logically consistent in my framework?" Te asks "does everyone agree this works and what do the numbers say?" Ti builds personal systems. Te implements group-validated systems. Totally different frequencies.
Which types have Ti?

Eight types use Ti. Hero position: INTP and ISTP. Parent position: ENTP and ESTP. Child position: INFJ and ISFJ. Inferior position: ENFJ and ESFJ. The higher Ti sits in your stack, the faster and more refined your logical processing runs. Ti heroes are damn near impossible to argue with unless you bring flawless logic.
What does Ti hero look like?

Ti hero means you live and breathe logical consistency. INTP and ISTP types - they're running constant true-false checks on everything. Challenge their logic? You better come with bulletproof data and reasoning. They'll dismantle your argument point by point, and they're ruthless about it. Absolute truth matters more than your feelings. They build these intricate logical frameworks and defend them like fortresses.
How does an ISTP use Ti differently than an INTP?

ISTP has Ti hero with Se parent - they apply logic to physical, mechanical systems in real time. Think craftsman analyzing how machines actually work, building innovative contraptions. INTP has Ti hero with Ne parent - they apply logic to abstract possibilities and theoretical systems. They're methodical, building logical frameworks like Lego pieces. ISTP tests logic through doing. INTP tests logic through exploring what could be.
Why are Ti users seen as arrogant?

Because Ti users prioritize objective truth over your feelings. Period. They'll tell you the hard facts even when it hurts because absolute truth matters more than emotional comfort. That unwavering focus on logical consistency reads as arrogance to people who value social harmony. But here's the thing - they genuinely believe confronting harsh realities leads to growth. Truth over comfort, every damn time.
What's the relationship between Ti and Fe?

Ti and Fe are a paired axis - they're literally opposite ends of the same stick. If you have Ti hero, you have Fe inferior. Ti parent pairs with Fe child. This creates constant tension between personal logic and collective ethics. Ti burns away falsehoods to reveal truth - it's like fire. Fe nurtures and cares for others. Ti asks what's true, Fe asks what's good for people. You need both for balance.
How does ESTP use Ti parent?

ESTP has Ti parent with Se hero - they're the persuader type who tests rules and systems by breaking them. They'll intentionally violate boundaries to see if they're actually logical. Why does this rule exist? Let me test it in real life and find the weak points. They deconstruct systems mechanically, argue about every piece, then rebuild them better. It's pragmatic logic applied to present reality.
What does Ti child look like in INFJs?

Ti child in INFJ means their logic is innocent, playful, and powerful when engaged. They use it to verify their Ni insights - testing whether their visions are actually true. That Ti child makes them question everything internally, building logical frameworks to support their intuitions. But it's still developing, so they can be insecure about their reasoning. When you attack their logic, you're attacking their child function - and that wounds them deeply.
Why is it hard to change a Ti user's mind?

Because Ti users have already run thousands of true-false checks to build their logical framework. Every conclusion sits on a foundation of verified logic. You can't just present a feeling or appeal to majority opinion - that's meaningless to Ti. You need compelling data and airtight reasoning. Show them where their logic breaks down, give them better data, and they'll adapt. But your argument better be flawless or they'll dismantle it instantly.
How does Ti work with emotions?

Ti operates on true-false logic, but emotions absolutely color how Ti users perceive truth. That's the tension - they're seeking objective truth while their feelings influence what data they accept. Emotional responses can trigger Ti into defensive mode, blurring the line between thinking and feeling. Someone challenges their logic? That feeling response kicks in fast. Ti wants pure logic, but we're all human. The feelings are there whether Ti users admit it or not.
What's the difference between ethics and logic in cognitive functions?

Ethics is Fe - collective judgment of good versus bad based on group values. Logic is Ti - individual judgment of true versus false based on personal analysis. Ethics asks what's right for the tribe. Logic asks what's actually true regardless of the tribe. You can have something ethically good but logically false, or logically true but ethically problematic. These are completely different judging frequencies running in your mind.
How does ENTP use Ti parent?

ENTP has Ti parent with Ne hero - they're the rogue archetype who applies logic to future possibilities. Their Ne generates endless ideas and their Ti parent immediately stress-tests each one for logical consistency. They're less tied to existing systems than ESTP, more visionary. They'll tear apart conventional wisdom using logic, but they're focused on what could be rather than what is. That Ti parent keeps their wild Ne hero grounded in actual reasoning.
What keeps Ti from going too far?

Fe - extroverted feeling - keeps Ti in check. Ti can get so focused on absolute truth that it causes collateral damage, burning people in pursuit of logical purity. Fe brings ethics and care into the equation, asking "okay, but what about the people affected by this truth?" Te rationale also challenges Ti by bringing collective standards and measurable results. Ti needs these reality checks or it becomes destructive in its quest for pure logic.
What does Ti inferior look like in ENFJs?

Ti inferior in ENFJ means logic is their weakest, most insecure function. They lead with Fe hero - focused on ethics and caring for people - but their Ti sits at the bottom, underdeveloped and vulnerable. They struggle to verify truth logically, relying more on collective ethics than personal analysis. When stressed, that Ti inferior can grip them - suddenly they're paralyzed trying to logic their way out instead of using their natural Fe strength. It's their blind spot.
How do Ti users handle logical fallacies?

Ti users are hypersensitive to logical fallacies - ad hominem, straw man, all of it. They'll call that shit out immediately because it violates logical consistency. But here's the catch: Ti users can still fall into emotional reasoning themselves. They might dismiss an argument as fallacious when really it just triggered their feelings. Ti burns away falsehoods, but the user still has biases. Strong Ti means you're constantly checking for these fallacies in your own reasoning, not just others'.
Why do Ti and Te users clash?

Because they're using completely different standards for truth. Ti users verify everything through personal logical analysis - "I need to understand why this is true." Te users verify through collective validation and metrics - "everyone agrees this works and the data proves it." Ti sees Te as intellectually lazy, just following the herd. Te sees Ti as arrogant and inefficient, reinventing the wheel. Both are valid judging functions, just operating on different frequencies.
What role does Ti play in cognitive function stacks?

Ti is one of the eight cognitive functions - specifically, it's your introverted judging function for thinking. It's how you gather information and make decisions through personal logical analysis. Where Ti sits in your stack determines how naturally you access it. Hero or parent position? You're using Ti constantly, it's refined and powerful. Child or inferior? It's less developed, more vulnerable. Ti is the frequency your mind uses for true-false verification through individual reasoning.
How does Ti show up in everyday behavior?

Ti shows up in how you question everything, verify claims yourself, and build logical frameworks for understanding the world. You're the person asking "but why?" five layers deep. You test rules by breaking them to see if they make sense. You get frustrated when people accept things without proof. Even small actions reveal Ti - analyzing why your coffee tastes different, logically troubleshooting a broken appliance, or dismantling someone's argument piece by piece in conversation. It's constant true-false processing of reality.
What's the difference between ISTP and ESTP Ti usage?

Both have Ti, but different positions create different behavior. ISTP has Ti hero - they're the craftsman who lives in their logical framework, analyzing mechanical systems deeply and methodically. ESTP has Ti parent - they're the persuader who uses logic to challenge and test existing structures, breaking rules to expose weak points. ISTP builds and refines systems internally. ESTP tests and argues about systems externally. Same function, completely different expression based on stack position.
